resources.description: This ASCII text file describes the model data release. This file also includes a description of the model input and output files and instructions on how to run the models contained in this data release.
resources.name: readme.txt

resources.description: This ASCII text file defines the four corners of the model domain in decimal degrees.
resources.name: modelgeoref.txt

resources.description: This ZIP file contains ancillary data including directories with zonebudget fortran program and model-budget output. The directory includes GIS data used to generate figures. The directory also includes the ModelMuse program input files. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the ancillary/ subdirectory.
resources.name: ancillary.zip

resources.description: ZIP file containing the 64-bit executables for MODFOW-2005 and MODPATH6 used to run the passthru and stop simulations and complete the particle-traking analyses documented in the report (http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/sir20165138). The 64-bit ZONEBUDGET executable used to calculate water budgets for select portions of the groundwater model domain also is included. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the bin/ subdirectory.
resources.name: bin.zip

resources.description: ZIP file containing a shapefile which defines the extent of the model domain and active portions of the model. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the georef/ subdirectory.
resources.name: georef.zip

resources.description: This ZIP file contains the input files for the passthru and stop simulations, as well as, the input files for the particle-tracking analysis completed for these two simualtions. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the model/ subdirectory.
resources.name: model.zip

resources.description: This ZIP file contains the list file, binary cell-by-cell budget, and head files for the passthru and stop simulations, as well as particle-tracking output for the ptpassthru and ptstop particle-tracking analysis. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the output/ subdirectory.
resources.name: output.zip

resources.description: ZIP file containing source files for MODFLOW-2005 and MODPATH6 used to run model simulations included in the data release. This ZIP file should be unzipped to the source/ subdirectory.
resources.name: source.zip

organization.description:
http://www.usgs.gov/
The USGS is a federal science agency that provides impartial information on the health of our ecosystems and environment, the natural hazards that threaten us, the natural resources we rely on, the impacts of climate and land-use change, and the core science systems that help us provide timely, relevant, and useable information.
organization.title: U.S. Geological Survey, Department of the Interior
organization.name: usgs-gov

name: modflow-2005-and-modpath6-models-used-to-delineate-areas-contributing-groundwater-to-selected-s
notes: A regional groundwater-flow model and particle-tracking program were used to delineate areas contributing groundwater to coastal and freshwater bodies and to estimate travel times from the water table to saline water bodies under average conditions from 1968 to 1983 on Long Island, New York. The coastal waters of Long Island are important economic and recreational resources for the region. The coastal water bodies receive freshwater from inflow of both surface water and groundwater, in addition to tidal exchanges of saltwater. Excessive nitrogen inputs associated with development and urbanization in the freshwater recharge areas to coastal water bodies can adversely affect marine and estuarine ecosystems. The results from this study will be beneficial for developing informed strategies to address nutrient loading to these systems, to provide a basis for additional scientific studies, and to engage the public. This is the first phase in the development of an updated groundwater-flow model for Long Island as part of the National Water Quality assessment Program (NAWQA). The study modified and used the model documented in the publication 'Simulation of the effects of development of the ground-water flow system of Long Island, New York by Herbert T. Buxton and Douglas A. Smolensky (https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/wri984069). This data release contains all of the model input and output files for the simulations described in the associated model documentation report (http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/sir20165138).

title: MODFLOW-2005 and MODPATH6 models used to delineate areas contributing groundwater to selected surface receiving waters for long-term average hydrologic stress conditions from 1968 to 1983, Long Island, New York
